bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John W. Hart, July 29, 1950

div1.p: Hench is delighted that the Cuban government honored Hart. He details his attempts to preserve and memorialize Building No. 1 at Camp Lazear, and asks if Hart encountered anyone in Cuba who might be able to help.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John W. Hart, July 29, 1950
div1.opener:
July 29, 1950
Dr. John W. Hart
Director, New Products Division
Sterling-Winthrop Research Institute
Ronsselaer, New York
My dear Doctor Hart:
div1.p:
Please forgive me for not answering sooner your interesting letter
of December 27. I have gotten hopelessly behind in my correspondence as a
result of cortisone.

I was delighted indeed that the Cuban government honored you.
I am so sorry to hear that they have done nothing in the way of even preserving
the little Building No. 1. As you remember, last time I was there I offered
to build myself a galvanized iron protection around it. With much protestation
the vice-president insisted that they wouldn't think of allowing me to do that.
They would have it done themselves. I would have done it without asking
permission except that the little building, as you know, has been made a
Cuban governmental “monument.” They set aside $50,000 for its protection
and approved tentatively plans that I had drawn up for memorializing the spot
but shortly thereafter the administration went out of office before anything
was done and succeeding administrations took no responsibility for previous
commitments. That is the Cuban way. Did you run into anyone there who seemed
to have any interest whatever in doing something practical instead of just talk.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH/mr
P. S. I suppose you saw that Mrs. Walter Reed, age over 90, died last Sunday.
